question: 'Principles - You are always responsible for managing your own PII. You need to be aware that careless behaviour could impact not just you but also your colleagues and our company reputation. If unclear, always ask the PII team for more support.\nGuidance: If you are applying for a DBS check which is unrelated to work (for example volunteering in your local community) then the application does not require work details. Only an ID check via a passport or driving license is required.\nFor STEM applications, this is different as this WILL need to have more details. Consult the STEM team for further guidance on this.

Principles:

You are responsible for protecting your personal information when booking hotels online.
Be cautious when providing personal information online, as it can be vulnerable to cyber attacks and data breaches.
Take necessary steps to ensure that your personal information is secure and protected.
Guidance:

When booking a hotel online, only provide the necessary personal information required for the reservation, such as name, email address, and phone number.
Avoid using public computers or public Wi-Fi networks to book hotels online, as they may not be secure.
Use a reputable and secure payment method, such as a credit card, to pay for your hotel reservation.
Review the hotel's privacy policy and understand how your personal information will be used and protected before making a reservation.
If you have any concerns or questions about the hotel's data privacy practices, contact the hotel's customer service department before making a reservation.
Consider using a virtual private network (VPN) when booking hotels online to protect your personal information.
Regularly review your bank and credit card statements to ensure that there are no unauthorized transactions.
If you notice any suspicious activity related to your personal information, report it immediately to the hotel's customer service department and your bank or credit card company.
